translated: Cheng weishi lun, fascicle 8
Composed by Bodhisattvas such as DharmapÄla
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on imperial command
These four conditions are established as ten causes based on the distinctions in meaning of fifteen bases.
How are they established based on fifteen bases?

The first is the base of speech, which refers to the nature of speech that arises from dharmas, names, and concepts. Based on this base, the reason of following speech is established. It means that based on this speech, one speaks about various meanings according to what one sees, hears, etc. This is the reason of what is spoken for what is able to be spoken.

Some treatises say this is names, concepts, and views. Because one speaks according to what one grasps in terms of characteristics and clings to according to names, if one relies on those explanations, it is then shown that this reason is the base of speech.

The second is the base of experience, which refers to the nature of what is observed and the ability to experience. Based on this base, the reason of observation is established. It means that observing this causes those matters to either arise, abide, be accomplished, or be attained. This is the reason of observation for that.

The fourth is the support of perfuming seeds, that is, internal and external seeds in an immature state. On the basis of this support, the projecting cause is established, because it is able to project its own distant result.

The fifth is the support of moistened seeds, that is, internal and external seeds in a mature state. On the basis of this support, the productive cause is established, because it is able to produce its own proximate result.

The sixth is the support of cessation without a remainder, that is, the similar and immediately antecedent condition of mind and mental activities.ğŸ”½The seventh is the support of objects, that is, the condition as object of mind and mental activities.

The eighth is the support of organs, that is, the six organs that are the support of mind and mental activities.ğŸ”½The ninth is the support of activity, that is, the activity of the instrument in the performance of an action, that is, the remaining aids to the actualization of seeds.
The tenth is the support of the doer, that is, the activity of the doer in the performance of an action, that is, the remaining aids to the actualization of seeds.
The eleventh is the support of true views, that is, pure views, that is, the ability to assist in attracting and realizing pure dharmas, excluding the attraction of ones own seeds.
In general, the six are established as the cause of assistance, because the first five assist in the production of impure dharmas, and the sixth assists in the production of pure dharmas.

The eleventh is the basis of conformity, that is, the various activities of the indeterminate, the impure, and the good, which are seeds, that conform to and assist dharmas of their own species that are superior. The cause of attraction is established on the basis of this basis.
That is, it is able to attract and generate activities of its own species that are superior, and it is able to attract and obtain unconditioned dharmas.

The twelfth is the basis of specific power, that is, conditioned dharmas each have a power to generate and realize their own results. The cause of specific determination is established on the basis of this basis, because each is able to generate its own realm, etc., as results, and each is able to obtain its own vehicle as a result.

The thirteenth is the basis of combination, that is, from the basis of grasping up to the basis of specific power, there is a power of combination in the generation, duration, completion, and acquisition of results. The cause of the same activity is established on the basis of this basis, because from the basis of contemplation up to the basis of specific determination, all are the same in having one activity, such as the generation, etc., of results.

The fourteenth is the foundation of obstruction, which refers to dharmas that obstruct the events of birth, abiding, and so forth. Obstructive causes are established on the basis of this foundation, because they are able to obstruct the events of birth and so forth.

The fifteenth is the foundation of nonobstruction, which refers to dharmas that do not obstruct the events of birth, abiding, and so forth. Nonobstructive causes are established on the basis of this foundation, because they do not obstruct the events of birth and so forth.
These ten causes are subsumed in two causes: the first is the productive cause, and the second is the circumstantial cause.
The BodhisattvabhÅ«mi SÄstra says that the projecting seed and the productive seed are called the productive cause, and the remaining causes are circumstantial causes.

This means that among the projecting, productive, attracting, differentiating, cooperating, and nonopposing seeds of the causes and conditions, those that are not yet mature are called projecting seeds, and those that are mature are called productive seeds.
Because all the seeds of causes and conditions among the six causes are included in these two states.

The cause that is able to generate is the cause that is separated from the present state of activity, as the four causes that generate their own seeds, but it is often interrupted and therefore is not mentioned here.
Or, a cause that directly produces results is also called a seed, as in the case of the seeds of present actual dharmas such as grain and wheat.

translated: The remaining causes are the first two, the fifth, and the ninth, and the non-pervading dharmas among the six causes, which are the remaining causes of the cause that is the condition as cause of the cause that generates and the cause that matures. Therefore they are generally said to be included in the facilitating cause.
These two kinds of causes are not only the two causes mentioned above, because the cause that is the condition as cause is included in the remaining four causes.
The remaining causes are not only the eight causes mentioned above, because the two causes mentioned above also include the non-pervading dharmas.
The stages with applied thought, etc., say that the generating cause is the cause that generates, and the others are included in the facilitating cause.

The meaning of this passage is that among the six causes, the present and seeds that are the condition as cause are all called generating causes, because they are able to directly generate results of the same species.

The remaining causes are all included in the facilitating causes, because the generation of this consciousness is not due to that cause alone, because the other five causes include the cause of similar species.
It is not only the remaining causes that are not called projecting causes, because the projecting cause includes the cause of similar species that is not a cause of direct result.
Or, the projecting and productive seeds mentioned in the BodhisattvabhÅ«mi are the two causes, and the remaining causes are the other eight.
Even though there are causes in the two causes that are not productive causes, the seeds of direct results are predominant and manifest and for that reason are mentioned.
Even though there are causes in the remaining causes that are not facilitating causes, the dominant ones are manifest and for that reason are mentioned.

translated: The BhÅ«mi-vastu says that the productive cause is the productive cause and the others are the facilitating causes. The productive cause is the productive cause, and the other causes should be understood as the other nine.ğŸ”½Even though there are seeds in the productive cause that are not causes of direct results, they are close to the result and manifest and for that reason are mentioned.
Even though there are seeds of direct results in the projecting cause, they are distant from the result and hidden and for that reason are not mentioned.
The other perfuming conditions should be understood in the same way.
On the basis of which of the ten kinds of foundational consciousness are the four conditions established?
How are they included in the ten causes and two causes?

The treatise says that the condition as cause is established on the basis of seeds, the condition as object is established on the basis of the objective realm, and the dominant condition is established on the basis of the remaining ones.
Among these, seeds are included in the condition as cause of the third, fourth, eleventh, twelfth, thirteenth, fifteenth, and sixteenth foundational conscious nesses.
Even though the other four foundational consciousnesses have the condition as cause, it is often interrupted and therefore is not mentioned here.
Or, like wheat, etc., in the external world, they are also called seeds because they are able to directly produce their own results.
Or, the term seeds refers only to the fourth foundational consciousness, and the reasons for this are as before.

The phrase the immediately antecedent state of mind that has perished and the objective realm should be understood as generally indicating the two conditions and their ten foundational natures, not only the fifth and sixth. This is because the remaining foundational natures also have the meaning of the two conditions of the immediately antecedent and the condition as object.
Or there are only five or six. Although other places have more, they are hidden and are not mentioned.

The treatise says that the causal condition includes the productive cause, the dominant condition is the same as the expedient cause, and the middle two conditions are included in the supporting cause.
Although the expedient cause includes the latter three conditions, the dominant condition is predominant, so it is mentioned here.
The other causes also have the middle two conditions, but the supporting cause is prominent, so it is mentioned here.
The first productive cause is as discussed previously. The causal condition must have a result.
How many results are there?
Where are they obtained?
There are five kinds of results:
1. Ripened result, which is the good or bad dharmas that attract the ripening of one's own continuity, which is the indeterminate result of ripening.
2. Similar result, which is the same kind attracted by the practice of good, etc., or the subsequent result that resembles previous karma.
3. Dissociated result, which is the good unconditioned dharmas realized by the uncontaminated path in cutting off hindrances.
The fourth is the effect of human action, which is the work accomplished by the doer through the use of various tools.
The fifth is the effect of dominance, which is the remaining effects not included in the former four.

The YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi SÄstra and other texts say that the causal condition that is the seeds of perfuming produces the retribution result, the causal condition that is the support of similar and immediately antecedent states produces the similar result, the causal condition that is the correct view produces the result of separation, the causal condition that is the dominant condition produces the effect of dominance.

The words causal condition that is the seeds of perfuming indicate the power of all causal conditions to summon retribution results. The words causal condition that is the support of similar and immediately antecedent states indicate the power of all causal conditions to summon similar results. The words causal condition that is the correct view indicate the power of all causal conditions to summon the result of separation. The words causal condition that is the effect of human action indicate the power of all causal conditions to summon the effect of human action. The words causal condition that is the dominant condition indicate the power of all causal conditions to summon the effect of dominance.
If it were not so, the explanation would be too broad or too narrow.

translated: Or, the term habit energy refers only to the third condition, because although the cause of retribution is found elsewhere, and although there is a cause of retribution here that is not retribution, still the cause of retribution is far removed from its effect, and so is habit energy, and therefore it is said to be this.ğŸ”½The term conformity refers only to the eleventh condition, because although the effect of similar outflow is found elsewhere, and although this condition can also produce a result that is not outflow, still this cause is characterized by the production of superior qualities, and so is conformity, and therefore it is said to be this.

The term true view refers only to the tenth condition, because although the unconditioned is obtained elsewhere, and although this condition can also produce that which is not unconditioned, still this condition is characterized by the production of the unconditioned, and therefore it is said to be this.

The term human effort refers only to the ninth condition, because although the effect of human effort is found elsewhere, and although this condition can also produce the dominant effect, still the name is clear, and therefore it is said to be this.

The remaining eleven are only related to the other eleven bases. Although the other eleven bases also obtain the other fruits, and the other bases are also able to attract the dominant fruit, these eleven are mostly able to attract the dominant fruit. The other bases have already been explained, and therefore these are mentioned in particular.

Thus, of these five fruits, the retribution fruit is obtained by the projecting, productive, particular, similar, non-obstructing causes, and the dominant condition.ğŸ”½The similar fruit is obtained by the projecting, productive, assisting, attracting, particular, similar, non-obstructing causes, and the first and last conditions.ğŸ”½The disconnection fruit is obtained by the assisting, attracting, particular, similar, non-obstructing causes, and the dominant condition.
As for the fruit of human action, there is an interpretation that it is obtained by the contemplation, assisting, similar, non-obstructing causes, and the dominant condition.

According to another interpretation, it is obtained by the contemplation, projecting, productive, assisting, attracting, particular, similar, non-obstructing causes, and the three conditions excluding the condition as object.
As for the dominant fruit, it is possible that it is obtained by all ten causes and four conditions.
This digression is finished. We must now discuss the main point.
Seeds in the root consciousness can be the three conditions for the generation of actual, present, and past imaginations, excluding the condition as similar and immediately antecedent.
That is, each direct seed is the condition as cause for that result. It is the condition as object for that which is able to grasp an object.
If the seed has the power to assist or not obstruct, it is the dominant condition.
You should understand that the same is true of the generation of pure actual dharmas.
As for the mutual relationship of actual imaginations, they can be the three conditions for each other, because they do not have the condition as cause.
That is, the various classes of sentient beings can be the two conditions for each other, excluding the condition as similar and immediately antecedent.
The eight consciousnesses of a single being can be the dominant condition for each other, but they definitely do not have the condition as similar and immediately antecedent.

The meaning of the condition as object is sometimes absent and sometimes present. The eighth consciousness is the condition as object for the first seven consciousnesses, but the first seven are not the condition as object for the eighth. The reason is that the other seven are not the perceived objects of the eighth.

The seventh consciousness is the condition as object for the first six consciousnesses, but the first five are not the condition as object for the seventh. The other six are not the condition as object for the seventh.
The sixth has none of the five, but the other five have it. The five consciousnesses have as objects only the images of the eighth consciousness.
The sixth has three kinds of objects in relation to itself in the past and future, but the other consciousnesses have only the first, because they take present objects.

If it is admitted that the seeing part of the five consciousnesses in the present takes as objects the images of the five consciousnesses in the past, then the five and the seventh have three kinds of objects in relation to each other in the past and future.
The first seven consciousnesses may be the condition as object for the eighth, because they form the seeds of its seeing and seen parts.

Consciousnesses of the same stage and different substances have only the dominant condition in relation to each other, because associated dharmas do not have the same supporting objects and do not act as conditions as objects for each other.

Or, if we refer to the seeing part, they do not act as conditions as objects for each other, but if we refer to the seen part, they do act as conditions as objects for each other.ğŸ”½This means that the seen parts of consciousnesses of the same stage act as objects for each other, just as the seeds in consciousness act as objects for such dharmas as contact. If this were not so, then the formless would have no objects.
Even if it is admitted that form is transformed in the formless realms, still the seeds must be the objects, because the objects of the seeing part are not the same as the objects of the seen part.
The seen part of the same substance is the condition as object for the seeing part, but the seeing part is only the dominant condition for the seen part.
The same is true of the relationship between seeing and the self-authenticating part.
The other two parts are reciprocal conditions in two ways.
Here we are not speaking of seeds and the seen part, because we are speaking only of the reciprocal conditions of actual dharmas.
The pure and impure eight consciousnesses of self and others are reciprocal conditions in all ways, because they can universally take each other as objects.
However, the seeing part does not take the seen part as an object, because the seen part does not have the function of being an object.
Since actual dharmas that are present discrimination arise with seeds as a condition, seeds must also arise with actual dharmas and seeds as conditions.
How many conditions do actual dharmas and seeds as conditions for seeds?

Seeds do not arise from the middle two conditions, because the middle two conditions are established on the basis of mind and mental activities.ğŸ”½Actual dharmas as conditions for their own seeds are both conditions as cause and as direct antecedent, but for the seeds of other dharmas, they are only dominant conditions.
Seeds as conditions for their own seeds are both conditions as cause and as direct antecedent, but for the actual dharmas and seeds of other dharmas, they are only dominant conditions.
On the basis of this, the internal consciousnesses arise as reciprocal conditions, and the principles of the various kinds of discrimination and cause and effect are all established.
External conditions that are grasped as real may or may not exist, but even if they do exist, they are useless. Even more, they contradict reason and the teachings. Why insist on them?

Although the term discrimination generally refers to the mind and mental activities of the three realms, the holy teachings often show that it is predominant and is of many kinds, such as two, three, four, and five. This is discussed in detail in other treatises.
Even though there is internal consciousness, there are no external conditions. By what means do sentient beings continue in the cycle of death and rebirth?
A verse says:
The two graspings and their perfuming exist together.ğŸ”½When the previous retribution is exhausted,
another retribution is born.
The treatise says:
ACTIONS are meritorious, nonmeritorious, and nontransferable. They are impure good and bad volition.
The associates of action are also called action because they attract and complete the same retribution.

Although this action ceases without interval as soon as it occurs and has no power to attract a future retribution, it perfumes the root consciousness and produces its own power. This power is called perfuming.
The perfuming of the energies of action is the cause of the seeds of the two graspings. The seeds of the two graspings are perfuming, because they are perfumed by the energies of action.

These perfumings continue in a series until the time of fruition, when they attract a result that is retribution. This shows the dominant condition of the future result. The images, names, form and mind and mental functions, and the primary and derivative material elements, are all included in the two graspings.

The power of the two graspings perfumed and generated by these is the ability on the part of the root consciousness to produce the two graspings. This shows the seeds of the consciousness that is retribution in the future, as well as the seeds of its associated dharmas.
The word TOGETHER means that the seeds of action and the seeds of the two graspings are together, and this is the meaning of the mutual assistance of the remote and proximate conditions.
Action is manifest in attracting, and therefore the verse first mentions it.
PREVIOUS RETRIBUTION means the results that are retribution for actions in previous lives.
OTHER RETRIBUTION means the results that are retribution for actions in later lives.
Even though the seeds of the two graspings experience results forever, the perfuming of action experiences results and then comes to an end.

The reason is that the nature of the result of retribution is different and difficult to attract, while the nature of the result of similar activity and the dominant result is the same and easy to attract.
When the result of retribution of a previous life is exhausted due to the maturation of the seeds of karma, etc., that attract another life, it can again produce another result of retribution.
Therefore, the wheel of birth and death turns without end. Why assume that external conditions are necessary for the continuity of life?
The meaning of this verse is that the wheel of birth and death of the three realms of existence is not apart from consciousness, because mind and its activities are the nature of the three realms.
Next, the continuity of birth and death is due to habit energy. There are three kinds of habit energy in general:
1. Habit energy of names and expressions, i.e., the special seeds of conditioned dharmas.
Names and expressions are of two kinds:
1. Names and expressions that indicate meaning, i.e., the differences in sounds that express meaning;
2. Names and expressions that reveal objects, i.e., mind and its activities that perceive objects.
Seeds perfumed by the two kinds of names and expressions act as the specific causes and conditions of conditioned dharmas.
The second is the perfuming of the propensities of the grasping of a self, that is, the seeds of the false grasping of a self and what belongs to a self.
There are two kinds of grasping of a self:
the first is innate grasping of a self, that is, the grasping of a self and what belongs to a self eliminated by the path of cultivation;
the second is the grasping of a self as a result of discrimination, that is, the grasping of a self and what belongs to a self eliminated by the path of insight.
The seeds perfumed by the two kinds of grasping of a self cause the distinction of self and others among sentient beings.
The third is the perfuming of the propensities of the aggregates of becoming, that is, the seeds of karma that summon transmigration in the three realms.
There are two kinds of aggregates of becoming:
the first is impure good , that is, karma that summons agreeable results;
the second is all that is bad , that is, karma that summons disagreeable results.
The seeds perfumed by the two aggregates of becoming cause the distinction of good and evil destinies as the results of retribution.
You should know that the perfuming of the propensities of the grasping of a self and the aggregates of becoming are dominant conditions for the differentiated results.
The perfuming of karma mentioned in this verse should be understood as the perfuming of the aggregates of becoming.

You should know that the two propensities of the two graspings are the two propensities of self-attachment and verbal expression, because they perfume and form the propensities of grasping a self and grasping a selfâ€™s possessions and of grasping verbal expression.
The meaning of the remaining words such as â€œtogetherâ€ is the same as the previous explanation.
Next, the continuation of birth and death is due to delusion, karma, and suffering.

The passions that instigate karma and nourish birth are called delusion. The various karmas that attract future existence are called karma. The various sufferings attracted by karma are called suffering.
The seeds of delusion, karma, and suffering are all called propensities.
The first two propensities are the dominant conditions for the suffering of birth and death, because they assist in the production of suffering.
The third propensity is able to act as the condition as cause for the suffering of birth and death, because it directly produces suffering.
The three propensities of the verse should be understood as appropriate.
Delusion and suffering are called grasping, because they are the grasper and the grasped.
Grasping means attachment, and karma does not receive the name.
The meaning of the remaining words such as â€œtogetherâ€ is the same as the previous explanation.

It should be understood that these passions, actions, and sufferings include the twelve members of the chain of causation, i.e., from ignorance to old age and death, as explained in detail in the treatises.
However, the twelve members are summarized in four groups:
The first is the members that project, i.e., ignorance and the karmic forces, because they project the five results consisting of the seeds of consciousness, etc.
Here, ignorance refers only to that which instigates the performance of good and evil actions that definitely produce results in a subsequent life.
That which is instigated is called the karmic forces.

Consequently, all actions whose results are experienced in the present life and all actions that assist in the production of future results are not members of the chain that constitute the karmic forces.

The second is the members that are projected, i.e., the seeds of the five results, consciousness, etc., that are included in the store consciousness and that are born with it. They are projected by the first two members.
Here, the seeds of consciousness are the causes of the store consciousness.
With the exception of the last three causes, the remaining causes are all included in the seeds of name-and-form.
The last three causes are the seeds of the last three members.
Alternatively, the seeds of name-and-form include the five causes, and the other four seeds are established on the basis of the preeminence of one of the five in a given case.
The same is true of the six sense bases and consciousness.

The Abhidharmasamuccaya says that consciousness is also that which projects, because the seeds of action in consciousness are called the member of consciousness. The seeds of consciousness as retribution are included in name-and-form.

A scripture says that the member of consciousness is both that which is projected and that which projects, because both the seeds of action and the seeds of consciousness are called consciousness, and because consciousness is the support of name-and-form, but is not itself included in name-and-form.

Even though the five seeds of consciousness, etc., are really simultaneous, being perfumed and producing by action, they are said to be in a temporal sequence in the holy teachings because of differences of master and servant, totality and particularity, superiority and inferiority, and cause and effect.
Or, they are said to be in a temporal sequence because of a sequence in the future actual state.
Consequently, consciousness, etc., are also said to be actual dharmas, because at the time of the cause there is no meaning of actual activity.
Also, because of this, it is said that birth and projection are simultaneous, because the time of moisture and lack of moisture is never simultaneous.
The third is the member that generates, consisting of thirst, grasping, and becoming, because they are proximate in generating future birth, old age, and death.

That is, ignorance of internal results as retribution produces actions that definitely bring about rebirth. Ignorance of external dominant results produces craving for objects of the six sense consciousnesses. Craving in turn produces the four kinds of grasping. Craving and grasping together moisten the seeds of action and the seeds that are attracted by those actions, and this is called becoming, because it is close to having a later result.
Some sources say that only the seeds of action are called becoming, because they are able to directly summon retribution.
Some sources say that only the five seeds are called becoming, because they are close to producing the future consciousness, etc.
The fourth is the members that are produced, that is, birth and old age and death, because they are produced by craving, grasping, and becoming.

That is, from the intermediate existence until the present existence, before the stage of decay, this is called the member of birth. All stages of decay are generally called old age, and the end of life and the breaking up of the body are called death.
Old age is not definitely existent and is added to death to make a member.
Why is illness not a member?
Because it is neither universal nor fixed.
Although old age is not fixed, it is universal and therefore established as a member, because all worlds, destinies, and forms of birth have decay and death except for those who die prematurely.
Name-and-form is not universal. Why is it established as a member?
Because it is fixed. For those born from wombs, embryos, or moisture, before the six sense bases are complete, name-and-form is fixed.

Also, the member of name-and-form is also universally existent. For those born by transformation in the realm of form, although they have the five sense organs at the time of first receiving life, they are not yet functioning, and at that time it is not called the member of the six sense bases.
Although those who are first born in the formless realm definitely have the mental faculty, it is not clear, and it is not called the mental sense base.
Therefore the treatise says that the twelve members all exist in the upper two realms in part.
Craving is not universal. Why is it separately established as a member?ğŸ”½Because it is fixed. Those born in evil destinies do not crave them.
Those born in good destinies definitely have craving and do not seek nonexistence.
Although the love that nourishes rebirth does not occur in nonreturners, still, like the grasping that occurs in them, it definitely exists in seeds.
Also, love is universal, because those who are born in evil destinies have love for their present bodies.
The scriptures say that love does not exist in evil destinies, but this refers to the absence of love that seeks a body in evil destinies, not to the total absence of love.
Why are birth and old age and death established as that which is produced, and why are the five members of consciousness, etc., established as that which projects?
Because the characteristics of the causal state are difficult to know, the five members are established separately on the basis of the future effects.

That is, at the time of the linking of conception, the characteristics of consciousness are evident. Next, when the sense organs are not yet complete, the characteristics of name-and-form increase. Next, when the sense organs are complete, the six sense bases are bright and flourishing. On the basis of this, contact arises, and because of contact, feeling occurs. At that time, it is said that the experience of the effect is finally completed.

On the basis of this state of effect, the five causes are established. Because the characteristics of the state of effect are easy to understand, two members are established in summary to reveal the three kinds of suffering.
However, if the effect that is produced is in the future, birth, old age, and death are mentioned in order to generate aversion.
When it reaches the present, in order to make one understand the arising of the characteristics of the state, it is said that the five, consciousness, etc., are established.
Why is it that in the stage of projecting the cause of birth, ignorance is established in general, and in the stage of nourishing the cause of birth, craving and grasping are established separately?

Even though all passions are able to project and nourish, still in the stage of projecting the cause of birth, the power of ignorance is dominant, because it is endowed with eleven kinds of superiority, such as the object, etc., as is extensively explained in the scriptures.

In the stage of nourishing the cause of birth, the power of craving is dominant, because it is said that craving is like water that can moisten. It is necessary to water frequently before the sprout of existence can be born.
Moreover, it is only in the first and last of the two, craving and grasping, that there is the meaning of repeated projection, and therefore one ignorance is established.
Even though the member of grasping includes all passions, still craving is the most important, and therefore it is said that craving increases.

All members of conditioned arising are based on their own stages, but in the case of the performance of action, it is based on the ignorance of another stage, just as the ignorance of a lower stage projects the action of a superior stage.

If it were not so, then the superior samÄdhi produced by one who has temporarily subdued the passions of a lower stage would not be a member of action, because the ignorance of that stage has not yet arisen.
When one is born in a lower or higher stage from a higher or lower stage, what feeling does one take as an object when one generates the member of craving?
This craving also has as an object the feeling of the stage where one will be born, whether actual or as seeds. There is no disagreement with reason.

The ten causes and two results of the twelve members are definitely not the same in temporal period. The first seven members and the members of thirst, grasping, and becoming are sometimes the same and sometimes not. The second, third, and seventh members are definitely the same in temporal period.

In this way, one cycle of cause and effect of the twelve members is sufficient to show the turning of the wheel of death and rebirth and to avoid the errors of eternalism and nihilism. The establishment of two cycles is really useless, or else there would be an infinite regress.

As for the different meanings of the twelve members, nine are real dharmas and three are fictional, because the six members after thirst are combined to form becoming, and the five members of consciousness, etc., are distinguished according to different states of the three appearances of birth, etc.
Five members are single events, i.e., ignorance, consciousness, contact, feeling, and thirst, because the remaining members are not single events.

Three members are only impure, because they are by nature passions. Seven members are only pure, because they are results as retribution. The seven states may contain impurity, because they may generate passions.
The remaining ten are of both kinds.
Ignorance, craving, and grasping are called unique characteristics because they are not mixed with other members. The remaining members are mixed characteristics.
Six are not form, namely, ignorance, consciousness, contact, feeling, craving, and grasping. The remaining ten are of both kinds.
All are impure and included in the conditioned, because pure and unconditioned dharmas are not members of existence.

Ignorance, craving, and grasping are only non-good and defiled indeterminate. Volitional action is only good and bad. Becoming is good, bad, and undefiled indeterminate. The remaining seven are only undefiled indeterminate.
Although all are found in the three realms, some are found in part and some in their entirety.
The member of existence of a higher stage can subdue that of a lower stage, because it has the six aspects of coarseness, suffering, etc., and one seeks birth in a higher stage and produces it.
All are produced only by non-learners and non-post-learners.

Because it is clear that good karma with outflows is a condition for the arising of the consciousness that is retribution, and because it opposes the member of existence, it is not categorized as existence.

Consequently, you should understand that holy beings definitely do not create karma that will engender a subsequent existence, because they are not confused and do not seek suffering in a subsequent life.
It is not contradictory in principle to say that the perfuming of the impure meditations perfects the karma of the lower stages and generates birth in the Pure Abodes, etc.

There is an interpretation that ignorance is only eliminated by the path of insight, because it is necessary to be confused about the four truths in order to generate the twelve members of the chain of existence, and because holy teachings say that holy beings definitely do not create karma that will engender a subsequent existence.
The two members of craving and grasping are only eliminated by the path of cultivation, because one seeks a future existence through craving and moistens birth through grasping.
Because the nine kinds of minds at death are associated with craving, the remaining nine members are eliminated by both the paths of insight and cultivation.

There is an interpretation that all members are eliminated by both paths, because a treatise says that the state of streamenterer has eliminated a part of the member of existence, but none have eliminated it completely.
If the member of ignorance is eliminated only by the path of insight, why does the treatise say that none have eliminated it completely?
If craving and grasping are only eliminated by the path of cultivation, how can it be said that one part of all members is eliminated?

Also, it is said that all passions of the three realms bind one to birth and death. Only passions that are eliminated by the path of insight can generate the act of going to evil destinies, and it is not said that only passions eliminated by the path of cultivation can moisten birth. All acts that attract subsequent existence are generated by the passions eliminated by the path of insight. For this reason, we know that the three members of ignorance, thirst, and grasping are also eliminated by the path of insight as well as by the path of cultivation.
However, the member of ignorance that directly generates acts is only eliminated by the path of insight, while that which assists is not fixed.
The two members of thirst and grasping that directly moisten birth are only eliminated by the path of cultivation, while that which assists is not fixed.
Also, defiled dharmas are to be eliminated by nature, because when their antidote arises, they are eternally eliminated.
All impure dharmas that are not defiled are not to be eliminated by nature, because they do not oppose the path.
However, there are two meanings of elimination. The first is elimination by separation from bonds, that is, eliminating the bonds and the passions that are mixed with them.
The second is elimination by nonproduction, that is, eliminating the support of those passions so that they are eternally unproduced.
It is said that contaminated good and nondefiled and nondetermined dharmas are only eliminated by cultivation, because they are eliminated by the separation from bonds.
It is said that evil destinies, nonperception, etc., are only eliminated by the path of insight, because they are eliminated by the nonarising of future dharmas.
As for the statement that the twelve members are eliminated by both paths, this should be understood as appropriate in the above eliminations.
Ten members are associated with pleasure and indifference, because feeling is not associated with itself.
Because in the state of old age and death, there is mostly no pleasure or indifference.
Eleven members are associated with suffering, because they are not associated with feeling.

Eleven members are partially categorized as the suffering of change, because in the state of old age and death, there is mostly no feeling of pleasure. It is not said that they are categorized as the suffering of change, because the suffering of change is established on the basis of pleasure.
Twelve members are partially categorized as the suffering of suffering, because all members contain the feeling of suffering.
Twelve members are categorized as the suffering of the karmic process, because all contaminated dharmas are the suffering of the karmic process.

It is said that eleven members are partially categorized as the suffering of the karmic process, because they are based on the feeling of indifference. The member of old age and death is excluded, as in the case of the suffering of change. This is the true interpretation.
The scriptures do not agree as to which of the twelve members is dominant, but all are included in the truth of suffering, because they are by nature the aggregates that are grasped.
Five members are also included in the truth of the origin of suffering, because they are by nature action and passions.
The twelve members are definitely dominant conditions for each other, but the remaining three conditions, i.e., causal, similar , and sovereign, may or may not exist among the members.
The scriptures only speak of one condition, i.e., dominant condition, because they are speaking from the point of view of certainty.
There is a causal condition from thirst to grasping and from becoming to birth.
If the member of consciousness is the seeds of action, then there is a causal condition from karmic forces to consciousness, but there is no causal condition among the remaining members.
The Abhidharmasamuccaya says that there is a causal condition from ignorance to karmic forces, but this is said on the basis of the perfuming of action at the time of ignorance.
Because ignorance is associated with the seeds of action, it is figuratively referred to as ignorance, but in reality it is the seeds of action.

The YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra says that there is no causal condition among the members, but this is said on the basis of the fact that only action exists in the present and thirst and grasping are not present.
There are two conditions, causal and similar , from ignorance to karmic forces, from thirst to grasping, and from birth to old age and death.
Birth has a similar and immediately antecedent condition and an object as condition, but not a dominant condition.
The remaining members are not related to each other in either of the two ways.
This is the explanation of the real process of dependent arising in terms of its members in immediate succession, in regular order, and without confusion.
If we consider the members in other ways, such as in irregular order, the conditions are not fixed. The wise should consider them in accordance with reason.

The twelve members are included in the three categories of passions, actions, and suffering. Ignorance, craving, and grasping are categorized as passions. Karmic forces are categorized as actions. Seven members are categorized as suffering.
Some sources say that the category of action includes the member of becoming. You should understand that this is said with reference to the becoming of action.
Some sources say that the member of consciousness is categorized as action. This is said because the seeds of action are the member of consciousness.
Only that which is attracted by passions and actions is called suffering, because it is categorized as the truth of suffering, in order to generate disgust.
Since the twelve members are included in the three categories of passions, actions, and suffering, they are able to cause the continuation of birth and death.
Furthermore, the continuity of birth and death is due to internal causes and conditions, not external conditions, and therefore there is only consciousness.
Causes refer to the two kinds of karma, contaminated and uncontaminated, which directly produce birth and death, and are therefore called causes.

Conditions refer to the two kinds of obstacles, the obstacle of the passions and the obstacle to that which is to be known, which assist in producing birth and death, and are therefore called conditions.
Why is this?
There are two kinds of birth and death.

The first is the birth and death of the compounded, that is, the gross retribution of the three realms that is attracted by contaminated good and bad actions, by the power of the conditions of the passions that assist them. The body and life are short or long, depending on the power of causes and conditions, and there is a definite limit, and therefore it is called compounded.

The second is the inconceivable transformation of birth and death, that is, the subtle retribution of the special, fine, superior fruit that is attracted by the nondiscriminative karma of the bodhisattva, by the power of the conditions of the obstacle to that which is to be known that assist it. Because of the power of compassion and vows, the body and life are transformed and changed and have no definite limit, and therefore it is called transformation.
It is called inconceivable because the marvelous function of the retribution that is attracted and received by the power of pure samÄdhi and vows is difficult to fathom.
Or it is called a body created by mind, because it is created in accordance with the vow of mind.
As a scripture says, â€œConditioned by grasping, the cause of impure action continues subsequent existence and produces the three kinds of existence.â€

In the same way, the cause of impure action, which is the ground of nescience, produces the three kinds of bodies created by mind for arhats, pratyekabuddhas, and bodhisattvas who have attained mastery.
It is also called a transformation body, because it is transformed by the power of pure samÄdhi into something different from the original body, like a transformation.
As a treatise says, How can disciples who are learners and post-learners who have eternally exhausted future lives realize supreme bodhi?
They realize supreme bodhi by means of a transformation body, not by means of a body that is retribution for action. Therefore there is no contradiction with reason.

If the obstacle to that which is to be known assists pure action and can attract birth and death, those of the two vehicles of a fixed class would not eternally enter nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder, because they would be bound by the obstacle to that which is to be known, just as ordinary beings are bound by the passions.
How can the truth of the path really attract suffering?
Who says that it really attracts?
If not, how is it?
The pure concentrations and vows assist impure actions, causing the results obtained to continue for a long time and to increase and become excellent. It is metaphorically said that they attract.
When they attract in this way, the obstacle to that which is to be known assists by being a condition, but they are not able to attract by themselves.
However, the obstacle to that which is to be known does not obstruct liberation, because it has no power to generate actions and nourish birth.
What use is it to assist in attracting the suffering of birth and death?
It is for the sake of realizing bodhi and benefiting and gladdening others.

This refers to those of unfixed potential who are pratyekabuddhas, Å›rÄvakas, and bodhisattvas who have attained freedom through their great vows. Since they have eternally eliminated or subdued the obstacle of the passions, they are not subject to the future bodies of the transformation birth.

Fearing that they will neglect the practice of bodhisattvas for a long time, they use the power of pure, superior concentrations and vows, as in the method of prolonging life, to assist the causes of their present bodies and cause them to continue for a long time and not cease.
They assist in this way by means of concentration and vows many times, and continue until they realize supreme bodhi.
Why do they need the assistance of the obstacle to that which is to be known?

Since they have not yet realized the great compassion of the absence of characteristics, they do not grasp bodhi and sentient beings as really existing, and they are unable to generate the intense compassion and vows.
Also, the obstacle to that which is to be known obstructs great bodhi, and they retain their bodies and remain in the world for a long time in order to eliminate it forever.

Also, the obstacle to that which is to be known is the support of impure dharmas. If this obstacle did not exist, those impure dharmas would definitely not exist. Therefore it is a great auxiliary cause for the retention of the body.

If the body that is retained is assisted by impure samÄdhi and vows, it is categorized as a body of the class of cyclic existence, because it is an object perceived by the knowledge of adherents of the two vehicles and ordinary beings.
If it is assisted by pure samÄdhi and vows, it is categorized as a transformation body, because it is not an object perceived by the knowledge of adherents of the two vehicles and ordinary beings.
Consequently, you should understand that the transformatory birth and death of bodhisattvas is categorized as the result of retribution of impure dharmas, and it is a dominant result of pure actions.
In some holy teachings, it is said to be pure and to transcend the three realms. This is said with reference to its assisting causes.
The perfuming of action mentioned in the verse is the two kinds of seeds of action mentioned above.
The propensities of the two graspings are the seeds of the two hindrances mentioned above, because they are both attachments.
The meaning of the words â€œbothâ€ and so on is as explained above.

Although there is no parinirvÄá¹‡a in the transmutations of life and death, and the various karmic results of past lives are exhausted and are born anew, still, they are repeatedly assisted and transformed, and there is the meaning of the exhaustion of the former and the rebirth of the latter.
Although life and death are also perpetuated by the present, still the seeds definitely exist, and the verse speaks of them.
Or, in order to reveal that the cause and effect of true karmic retribution are all non-separately from the fundamental consciousness, the present is not mentioned.
The present cause of karmic retribution does not immediately give a result, and the evolving consciousnesses are interrupted and not retribution.

The wheel of life and death in the past, present, and future is not dependent on external conditions, and since it is due to internal consciousness, you should understand that the perpetuation of pure dharmas is also like this.

That is, from beginningless time, pure seeds exist by the power of perfuming of the pure dharmas of hearing, reflection, and meditation, etc., and are supported by the root consciousness. They increase and grow stronger through the repeated perfuming of the evolving consciousnesses, etc., until finally, at the time of becoming a Buddha, one transforms and abandons the originally defiled seeds of consciousness and transforms and obtains the pure seeds of consciousness, which support all the seeds of merit.
By the power of original vows, one produces all kinds of marvelous functions to the end of time, and their continuity is endless.
On the basis of this, one should understand that there is only internal consciousness.
If there is only consciousness, why did the World-Honored One say in many scriptures that there are three natures?
One should understand that the three natures are also not apart from consciousness.
Why is this?
A verse says:
The imagination of various things,
This imagined nature is essentially nonexistent.
Dependent on discrimination and conditions,
The perfected nature is always far removed from the previous nature,
Neither different nor not different,
Just like the nature of impermanence, etc., is not seen in this or that.
The treatise says:
Because it thoroughly and pervasively conceptualizes, it is called thorough conceptualization.
There are many types, so it is called those and those.

That is to say, it is the false imagination that thoroughly conceptualizes. It is precisely by means of those and those false imaginations that one thoroughly conceptualizes the various objects that are thoroughly conceptualized, namely, the self-natures and distinctions of aggregates, sense bases, elements, etc., whether dharmas or selves, that are falsely grasped.
The self-natures and distinctions that are falsely grasped are collectively called the self-natures thoroughly conceptualized.
This kind of self-nature is utterly non-existent, because it cannot be found through logical investigation and teachings.

Or, the first line shows the consciousness that thoroughly conceptualizes, the second line shows the objects that are thoroughly conceptualized, and the second half finally states that the self-natures of the selves and dharmas that are thoroughly conceptualized do not exist, because it has been extensively shown that they cannot be found.
What is the self-nature of the initial ability to thoroughly conceptualize?

There is an interpretation that the first seven consciousnesses and their mental activities, being impure, are all capable of universal imagination, because they all have as their nature false imagination, because they all appear resembling the grasped and the grasper, and because it is said that the Älaya consciousness has as its object the seeds of clinging to the imagined nature of things as a real self.

There is an interpretation that only the part of the sixth and seventh consciousnesses that grasp a self and grasp dharmas are the universal imager, because it is said that only mental consciousness is capable of universal imagination, because mind and mental consciousness are called mental consciousness, because it is imagination and discernment that are capable of universal imagination, because grasping a self and grasping dharmas must be discernment, because the two graspings must be associated with ignorance, because it is said that ignorance does not have a good nature, because delusion and nondelusion, etc., are not associated, because we have never seen a grasping that guides the knowledge of emptiness, because grasping existence and grasping nonexistence do not occur together, because there is no grasping that is not perfumable, and because impure minds, etc., do not realize reality. All are called false imagination.

Even though they appear as if they were the images of the grasped and grasper, not all of them are categorized as imagination, because it must not be said that pure minds also have grasping, and because the post-teaches of a TathÄgata would have grasping.
A scripture says that the knowledge of a Buddha manifests various images such as bodies and lands, like a mirror, etc. If it does not have a function of objects, it would not be knowledge, etc.

Even though it is said that the store consciousness has as its object the seeds of imagination, it is not said that it has only that as its object, and therefore this is not a conclusive piece of evidence.
As a result of this reasoning, imagination exists only in the sixth and seventh consciousnesses.

Even though there are two kinds of consciousnesses, there are different kinds of imagination, such as two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, etc., and therefore the text says IMAGINATION OF THAT AND THAT.
Next, what is the nature of that which is imagined?
The MahÄyÄnasaá¹ƒgraha says that it is the dependent on others, because it is the condition as object for the imagining mind, etc.
Why is the perfected nature not its object?
Because reality is not the object of false grasping.
It is said to be imagined on the basis of a secondary sense of the term.
Although the imagined nature is the object of the above two natures, it is not an objective condition, and therefore it is not said to be imagined.
What are the characteristics of the imagined nature?
How does it differ from the dependent on others?

There is an interpretation by Sthiramati that, from beginningless time, mind and mental activities of the three realms are perfumed by false imagination and, although each has only one substance, they are born resembling two parts, that is, the seeing and seen parts, which are the subjective and objective aspects of consciousness.
These two parts exist as a result of the feelings and ideas of beings, but in reality they do not exist.
These characteristics are said to be the imagined nature. The substance of the two parts is real, because it is based on conditions.
This nature is not nonexistent and is therefore called the dependent on others, because it is born of false imagination and discrimination.
How do we know this?
Various holy teachings say that false imagination is the dependent on others, and the two grasps are the imagined.

There is an interpretation by DharmapÄla that the two parts of consciousness that evolve from the power of perfuming of all mind and mental activities are also the dependent on others, because they are born from conditions.
On the basis of this dependent on others, one falsely grasps and determines that things are definitely real, non-existent, one, different, both, or neither, etc. These two are called the imagined.
Various holy teachings say that only the perceived, only the two, and only the manifold are all called dependent on others.
Also, the four dharmas of image, etc., and the eleven consciousnesses, etc., are all said in the treatises to be categorized as dependent on others.
If this were not so, the two parts of pure subsequently acquired knowledge would be called imagined.
If you admit this, then holy knowledge would not have them as objects, and the class of knowledge that has them as objects would not be the truth of the path.
If you do not admit this, you must understand that the same is true of the impure.
Also, if the two parts are imagined, they would be like the horns of a rabbit, etc., and would not be conditions as objects, because the substance of the imagined does not exist.
Also, the two parts would not perfume and form seeds, and the two parts would not exist in subsequently arising consciousnesses.
Also, perfuming is categorized as the seen part. How can it not be a real dharma that can act as a condition as cause?

If the internal seeing part and seeing part that are born of conditions are not dependent on others, the substance that is the support of the two must be the same, because there is no different cause.

As a consequence of this principle, the substance of mind and mental activities born of a combination of conditions, as well as the seeing parts and the seen parts, whether impure or pure, are all dependent on others, because they are born by depending on a combination of conditions.

The words IMAGINATION THAT SEES THE TWO ENTITIES BORN OF CONDITIONS should be understood as referring only to the defiled part of the dependent on others, because the pure part of the dependent on others is also the perfectly accomplished nature.
Or, all defiled and pure minds and mental activities are called imagination, because they are able to imagine and think.

In that case, all defiled and pure dependent on others are included in this dependent on others.ğŸ”½The perfectly accomplished nature is the true nature of dharmas as revealed by the twofold emptiness. It is called perfectly accomplished because it is fully accomplished and perfected, because it is not false or deceptive, and because it distinguishes itself from the natures of self, person, universal and particular characteristics, space, and so forth.

Pure, conditioned dharmas, free from error and ultimate, and whose superior functioning is universal, are also called perfectly accomplished. However, the verse here speaks of the first and not the second.

This means that the perfected nature is, by its very nature, the true suchness revealed by the twofold emptiness, which is always and forever devoid of the previously mentioned nature of the dependent on others.
The words ABOUT THAT indicate that the perfected nature is neither identical with nor different from the dependent on others.
The words ALWAYS AND FOREVER DEVOID indicate that the nature of grasped and grasper, falsely imagined by delusion, is eternally nonexistent.

The words NOT EMPTY indicate that the dependent on others is not empty, and the words NATURE indicates that the twofold emptiness is not the perfected nature, because true suchness is devoid of existence and devoid of nonexistence.

Consequently, the perfected nature is neither different nor not different from the dependent on others. If it were different, true suchness would not be its true nature. If it were not different, this nature would be impermanent.
Both would be objects that are pure and impure, and the functions of the knowledge of the first seven stages and that of the eighth stage would not differ.
How can these two natures be neither different nor identical?
They are like the natures of impermanence, no self, etc.
If impermanence, etc., were different from such dharmas as form, these dharmas would not be impermanent, etc. If not different from them, it would not be their universal characteristic.
Therefore, the metaphor shows that the perfected nature is neither identical to nor different from the dependent on others.
The principle that dharmas and their true nature must be so is because the ultimate truth and the conventional are mutually dependent.

Without realizing the perfected nature, one cannot see the dependent on others, because without penetrating the emptiness of the imagined nature, one does not know the dependent on others as it really is.
When nondiscriminative cognition realizes true suchness, subsequently acquired cognition is then able to understand the dependent on others as being like an illusion, etc.

Even though since beginningless time the mind and mental activities have been able to take as objects their own natures, seen divisions, etc., still they are always accompanied by the grasping of selves and dharmas and therefore do not know as they really are the false transformations of oneâ€™s own mind and mental activities attracted by various conditions, which are like an illusion, a mirage, a dream image, a reflected image, an echo, a moon in the water, and a magical creation, i.e., existing as if they do not exist.
In accordance with this meaning, there is a verse that says:
One cannot understand that all activities are like illusions, etc., that although they exist, they are not real,
without seeing suchness.

The meaning here is that the three natures are not apart from mind and mental factors. This is because mind, mental factors, and their transformations arise from many conditions, like illusions, etc. They are not existent but seem to be existent, deceiving fools. All are called the nature of dependent arising.

Fools falsely grasp a self and dharmas as existent or nonexistent, the same or different, both or neither, etc., like the nature and characteristics of flowers in the sky, which are completely nonexistent. All are called the nature of discrimination.
The self and dharmas falsely grasped as existing on the basis of dependent arising are both empty. The true nature of consciousness, etc., revealed by this emptiness is called the perfected nature.
Therefore, these three are not apart from mind, etc.
To which nature do space, cessation through discrimination, and cessation not through discrimination belong?
All three are possible. Transformations of mind, etc., that appear as the characteristics of space, etc., are categorized as the nature of dependent arising because they arise from mind.
The foolish and ignorant falsely grasp them as really existing, and they are categorized as the imagined nature.
If the meaning of space, etc., is provisionally established as existing in suchness, it is categorized as the perfected nature.
It is certain that impure minds, etc., belong to the dependent on others, but pure minds, etc., may be categorized as either of two natures.
Because they are born of a combination of causes and conditions, they are categorized as the dependent on others, but because they are devoid of error, they are categorized as the perfected.
How are these three natures related to the seven kinds of suchness?
The seven kinds of suchness are suchness of flowing and transforming , i.e., the reality nature of the flowing and transforming of dharmas;
suchness of true characteristics , i.e., the reality nature revealed by the two kinds of no-self;
suchness of consciousness only , i.e., the reality nature of dharmas of defilement and purity as consciousness only;
suchness of establishment , i.e., the reality nature of suffering;ğŸ”½suchness of error , i.e., the reality nature of the cause of suffering;
suchness of purity , i.e., the reality nature of the cessation of suffering;
and suchness of right practice , i.e., the reality nature of the path.
These seven are included in the perfected nature, because they are the objects of the two kinds of knowledge, that acquired at the root and that acquired subsequently.

As for their inclusion according to characteristics, the three natures of transmigration, suffering, and the cause of suffering are included in the first two natures, because they are false attachments and impure.
The remaining four natures are all included in the perfected nature.
How are the three natures and the six dharmas included?

All six dharmas are endowed with the three natures, because form, feeling, conceptualization, karmic forces, consciousness, and the unconditioned all have the principle of the reality of false imagination.
How are the three natures and the five dharmas included?
The holy teachings do not agree on the way of inclusion.

Some sources say that the other-dependent pattern includes the imagined pattern, name, and discrimination, and the perfected nature includes suchness. The imagined nature does not include the five dharmas.

These sources say that impure mind and mental activities transform to resemble the perceived object and are said to be the imagined pattern, and they manifest as resembling the perceiving subject and are established as name. The transforming mind, etc., are established as discrimination.
Because pure minds and so forth are free from idle discourse, they are simply called right knowledge in general and are not said to be the means and objects of knowledge.
The fourth is categorized as the dependent on others because it is produced from conditions.

Or, there are sources that say that the dependent on others is categorized as the images and discrimination, the imagined is categorized as names, and right knowledge and true suchness are categorized as the perfectly real.
This means that the images of impure minds and mental activities are called images, and the rest are called discrimination.
The imagined is totally devoid of substance, and in order to show that it does not exist, it is metaphorically said to be names.
The two latter natures are categorized as the perfectly real because they are free from error.

Or, there are sources that say that the dependent on others is categorized as discrimination, the imagined is categorized as images and names, and right knowledge and true suchness are categorized as the perfectly real.
This means that impure minds and mental activities, such as the seeing part and seen part, etc., are generally called discrimination, because false imagination is their intrinsic nature.
The expressed and the means of expression of the imagined are established as the two things of images and names according to ones feelings.
There are also places where it is said that it belongs to the nature of dependent arising, and the meaning belongs to the nature of universal imagination.
That means that the images and seeing parts of the contaminated mind and mental activities are imagined by the power of names, and therefore they are called names.
The nature of universal imagination is falsely imagined according to names, and its substance is really nonexistent. It is given the name of meaning.
The five things mentioned in various holy teachings have different words but the same meaning.
However, the first explanation is not confused, and it should be understood in detail as in the YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra.
Also, the holy teachings say that there are five characteristics. How are these related to the three natures?

The objects and names each have the three natures. That is, the falsely imagined is categorized as the first nature. The images, names, and conceptualization, in accordance with what is appropriate, are categorized as the objects and names of the dependent on others, and the true suchness and correct knowledge, in accordance with what is appropriate, are categorized as the objects and names of the perfected, because the subsequently acquired  appears as if it were the characteristics of the objects and names.
The characteristic of association is categorized as the first nature, because the meaning of the name is definitely associated with the object.
The characteristic of attachment is categorized as the dependent on others, because false imagination is its essence.
The characteristic of nonattachment is categorized as the perfected, because pure knowledge, etc., is its essence.
Also, how are the four realities taught in the holy teachings categorized in terms of the three natures?
The reality established by worldly reasoning is categorized as the dependent on others, because it is categorized as the three things.
The reality experienced by the pure knowledge that eliminates the two obstacles is categorized as the perfected, because it is categorized as the last two things.
The MadhyÄntavibhÄga says that the first reality is categorized as the first nature, because it is generally grasped.
The second reality is common to the three natures, because it is generally grasped and not grasped, and is both impure and pure.
The last two realities are categorized as the third nature.
How are the three natures related to the four holy truths?
Each of the four truths is endowed with the three natures.
Moreover, in the truth of suffering, the four such as impermanence each have three natures.
The three kinds of impermanence are: first, impermanence of no nature, because its nature is always nonexistent;
second, impermanence of arising and ceasing, because it has arising and ceasing;
third, impermanence of defilement and purity, because its state changes.
The three kinds of suffering are: first, suffering of what is grasped, because it is the basis for grasping of the two attachments to self and dharmas;
second, suffering of the characteristics of phenomena, because it has the characteristics of the three kinds of suffering;
third, suffering of combination, because the characteristics of suffering combine.
The three kinds of emptiness are: first, emptiness of no nature, because its nature does not exist;
second, emptiness of different natures, because it is different from the self-nature falsely grasped;
third, emptiness of self-nature, because what is revealed by the two kinds of emptiness is its self-nature.
The three kinds of no-self are: first, no-self of no characteristics, because the characteristic of self does not exist;
second, no-self of different characteristics, because it is different from the characteristic of self falsely grasped;
third, no-self of self-characteristics, because what is revealed by no-self is its self-characteristic.

The three kinds of truth of accumulation are the accumulation of habits, that is, the habits of grasping a self-nature of the imagined nature, and the name of that grasping is provisionally established on the basis of those habits;
the accumulation of the arising of the imagined nature, that is, karma and the passions;
the accumulation of non-separation from the obstacle, that is, true suchness that is not yet separated from the obstacle.
The three kinds of truth of cessation are cessation as a nature, because the nature is not born;
cessation as the non-arising of the two graspings, that is, cessation through discrimination, because the two graspings do not arise;
cessation as the original nature, that is, true suchness.
The three kinds of truth of the path are the path of knowing pervasion, because it is able to know the imagined nature;
the path of complete elimination, because it is able to eliminate the nature that is dependent on others;
the path of realization, because it is able to realize the perfected nature.
However, the path of knowing pervasion also extends to the latter two. The seven, the three, and the three natures are explained in order.
Now, the three natures that are explained here are either provisional or real, and one should understand them according to reason.
How are the three natures related to the three gates of liberation?
In principle they are all related, but in terms of their characteristics each is related to one of the three gates.

The characteristics of emptiness, wishlessness, and signlessness should be understood as corresponding to the three natures. In addition, three forbearances of the nonproduction of things are born from the three gates of liberation. The first is the forbearance of the nonproduction of things that is based on original nonproduction. The second is the forbearance of the nonproduction of things that is based on spontaneous nonproduction. The third is the forbearance of the nonproduction of things that is based on the nonproduction of the passions and suffering. These three forbearances are the objects of the three gates of liberation.
How are the three natures related to the two truths?
You should know that the conventional truth is made up of the three natures, while the truth of ultimate truth is only the perfected nature.

There are three kinds of conventional truth: the first is the conventional truth of designation, the second is the conventional truth of function, and the third is the conventional truth of manifestation. You should understand that these three kinds of conventional truth correspond to the three natures.
There are three kinds of ultimate truth:
the first is the ultimate truth of meaning, that is, suchness, because it is the meaning of the supreme;
the second is the ultimate truth of attainment, that is, nirvÄá¹‡a, because it is the supreme attainment;
and the third is the ultimate truth of practice, that is, the holy path, because it is the supreme practice.
They are all included in the perfected nature because they are not inverted and are in accordance with what is appropriate.
What is the scope of the three natures?
The imagined nature is not the scope of any consciousness, because it does not exist by itself and is not the condition as object.
The ignorant grasp it as existing, but the saints understand it as nonexistent. It is also said to be the object of the consciousnesses of both the ignorant and the saints.
The dependent on others is the scope of two consciousnesses.
The perfected is the object of the consciousness of only the saints.
How many of the three natures are false and how many are real?
The imagined is said to be false because it is falsely established, but because it has no substance or characteristics, it is neither false nor real.

The dependent on others is both real and false. Because it is the nature of an aggregation, a continuum, and a state, it is said to be falsely existent. Because mind, mental activities, and form are born from conditions, it is said to be really existent.
If there is no real dharma, there is no false dharma, because the false is established on the basis of the real.
The perfected is only really existent, because it is not established on the basis of other conditions.
Are these three different or not different?
It should be said that they are neither, because they have no separate substance, and because the true meaning of dependent arising is falsely grasped as separate.
The meanings and categories of these three natures are limitless, but fearing the tedium of extensive text, I have briefly indicated the essentials.Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Cheng weishi lun, fascicle 8
